title: How many total cases of COVID-19 in the U.S. will The COVID Tracking Project report as of Sunday 3 May 2020?
preds: Positives have been going up about 30,000 daily.

This looks like it will be right on the cusp, but based on previous weeks, the slow down in cases seems to be in Sunday to Monday, not Saturday to Sunday, so there should be at least 25k cases tomorrow.
This question comes down to the last day.  I'm with the crowd, just hedging a bit more.
Looks like being just over 1,150,000 but it's close!
Putting all the eggs in one basket.
Ok got it wrong. This is what it will be

May 1st saw a large increase in cases, with the number of tests conducted also increasing significantly.  The crowd has flipped to favor 1.15M to 1.2M.  The crowd is probably correct, but the final May 3rd number may hinge on the number of tests performed over the next two days.  Limits in test capacity could make the difference.
We're currently at 1.13 million confirmed cases with an average increase of 30,000 per day. It's extremely unlikely to decrease within the next 7 days.

Right now there is 1 095 681 positive through 1. May and the quantity increases each day (24K->27K->28K->36K), so if the trend stays same(even though it will probably worsen), that is at least 72K new cases in two days. But there is still 40K margin till 1.2M cases.
I wish there was more consistent and cohesive testing, but with current testing measures, this seems a fairly conservative estimate.
Based on average deaths and the likelihood that reported cases will maintain the same relationship currently experienced.

hi estimate:  1,164,xxx
lo estimate:  1,139,xxx
mid range:  1,150,251 Post mortem:  
Dang!  Wrong again!  And, again, too low!  I had intended to update my forecast last night, and forgot.  I would have gone to 83-86% for 1150,000-1200000.  But, I need to think about how I was too low both weeks, even though the outcome was very close to the cut-off.   This week, I paid more attention to the data, and noticed how daily totals change for prior days.
I've under-estimated the number of tests both weeks. I wonder if we'll have a 3rd chance to forecast on one week!

Worldometers is now at 131k.
Covid tracking needs to do some really weird things to not fall within this range.
The  numbers are rising by 20 - 30k each day.

Cases continue to rise and opening business almost like the virus is gone in 2-3 weeks it will be even worse.   I suspect that republican governors will attempt to cover the losses to prevent the “way it makes the party look”
Estimating 1,153,000 --> close to the boundary.  It really could go either way.

General downtrend that would've left Sunday's total below 1,150,000 has been interrupted by the same fluctuation seen on previous weekends  If this continues into Sunday then we're likely to sparsely exceed the 1,150,000 line.  If not we'll come in just below it.  Am hedging on the pattern indicated by @kirkapp.  It's going to be a nail biter, though.

I took into account an expected undercount over the weekend, otherwise I would have swapped the probabilities for the "More than 1,100,000 but less than 1,150,000" and "Between 1,150,000 and 1,200,000, inclusive" categories.
Almost home on this one, highly variable fatality rate across the nation and over time.

The number of positive cases increases by ~28k per day on average (if you look at the last 10 days), however there is an uptick for weekend days. Fridays show approximately 33k, Saturdays are the highest at ~34K, and Sundays drop slightly to the mean of 28K. This is important because these are the days in question from my posting. Given these numbers I estimate the cases on May 3rd at 4pm to be approximately 1,156,101. Obviously this is excruciatingly close to middle two answers, and a gust of wind either way could put it in one category or the next. Perhaps the COVID Tracking Projects releases numbers later than usual Sunday, or perhaps the fri-sun averages are blown out of the water this week. Of course we cannot discount anything as impossible (unless the number has already been passed), but I deem a surge to above 1.2M highly unlikely (1%), and a delay is posting data, keeping cases 'posted' low, equally as unlikely. However I do give a slight advantage to one category over the other based simply on the model I created. Good luck everyone!
Current growth rate is 1.6% per day

I calculated the average change per day for the past 3 weeks, then graphed the past 2 weeks to look for overall trends. Overall, although there is variation, the trendline is slightly downward. My estimate was based on a potential average rise of 26,000 to 28,000 per day, for 3 days. I also anticipated a potential a slight increase due to easing of restrictions, and for that I used 29,000 per day as my estimate. It would still be under 1,150,000 in that case.
Exponential growth due to lockdown loosening, good weather and a ramp up in testing.

Positive result tests are averaging around 30K per day.  Current daily rate of positive results projects to just under 1,150,000 by May 3. However New tests and testing facilities have been coming online. This is likely to increase the rate of positive cases being reported to just over 1,150,000
Current rate of increase will take total over 1,150,000 by May 3, but there tends to be a lag over the weekend.
Some states are opening too early, others are on lockdown.
Number of Positives have been rising at about 5% and with states prematurely opening that trend should continue or increase further.

Average of previous 5 days' increases x 3 days + current caseload = 1,136,492.8. Allowing 15% for possibility that increased testing will drive up figures as per last weekend, in which case could be looking at driving into 1,150k-1,165k territory.  As per UK, very reluctant to predict US figures due to unreliable political conditions & reporting.

computational forecast using incremental data, tested with 30 and 50 days history, forecast very close to 1.15M which will give some chances to both buckets until last day very likely. Still giving some chances for harder decline to account for suprise. Weights are estimated using normal distribution around mean outcome.
1137,xxx based on my curve-fitting model. I'm noticing that the data for prior days changes during the week. . . eek!
Updating to put more in the middle band based on the current trend.

Cases are not trending downward as much as anticipated.  Because of more widely available testing?  "Presumed" cases are more frequently being reported as actual by some states? More emphasis on reporting?

My forecast shows a total of 1,138,00 CI 95% [1,117,000 ; 1,160,000] with an average daily positive rate of 27,944. With the number of days left, the US would have to average 29,633 to break 1,150,000.  Testing Increase: Testing has averaged ~225,000/day after the step change from the previous avg of ~150,000/day. Estimated at 220,000/day with the weekend coming up there is a drop.  Positive Rates: Have been as high as 20% but are now closer to 13% over the last 14 days. The graph shows a leveling off and a possible increase but I don't think that will happen for another week due to relaxation of restrictions. Estimated at ~13% for the forecast.  Social Changes: Certain states have reduced restrictions but any bump in positive cases will not be realized by closing of this challenge.

There is a growing trend right now and reporting is limited on the weekend so it's difficult to say if all statistics will be included. It's trending that more cases are being attributed to Covid, even if they aren't official due benefits so it's likely to be higher than actual.
Got some Brier score to burn, so I am laying all my chips on 1.1M-1.15 M. Three days left, the weekend is coming, and it'll be in the 25k-30k range per day.

Short timeframe, hopefully numbers will keep getting smaller and smaller.
numbers of new tests are lower than I anticipated, as is the % of new cases.

By my data projections, the final number of deaths on May 3rd will be between 1,132,094 and 1,186,667. Significant deviating is highly unlikely (2%) based on current data trends.

Key variables are the number of tests performed and % positive.
Daily number of tests is on an upward trajectory, but with a lot of daily variability. Given goal of achieiving 2 million tests per week by end of May, reasonable to assume testing numbers will increase, but no good reason to believe imminent sudden jump, so estimating range of 200 - 230K tests per day.
Positive test rate (positive results/total tests) is currently on downard trajectory, but no reason to believe there will be a sudden drop off in next few days, so estimating range of 11 - 14%.
Tracking for 1.154M from recent linear trends.

Thinking in print here . . .  About increases in testing:  I've read that DJT is promising that every state will be able to test 2% of its population per month:  that would mean .5% per week.  With 330m people, .5% per week would work out to 1,650,000, right?  Last week 1,526,787 people were tested.  So, achieving what DJT promised wouldn't mean such a huge increase.  On the other hand, if there is one universal cry, it is for more testing, so I wouldn't be surprised if the increase in testing exceeded DJT's goal. However, it appears to me that while an increase in the number of tests will certainly increase the number of new cases identified, the % of new cases found will decrease because not just the visibly sick will be tested.   What I saw when I was crunching the data from April 20-26th, was that on the 22nd, when the # of tests doubled, the PERCENT of new cases more than decreased by half, so the net result was only about 10% more new cases than on the prior day, not 100%. Then there's the impact of social distancing.  It should reduce the % of new cases, too.   So, I'm thinking that while there may be some to significant increases in testing, the % of new cases will fall so the number of new cases won't rise much more than it rose last week. @ikresnak says that DJT's goal was 2% on top of the current testing level, which would mean more than a doubling Am I missing something?  @marktscannell
Average daily rise over the last week is roughly 3.29%. Assuming there is a slight drop in average daily cases (consistent with trend), the number should be roughly: 1,175,000.

5 days left, 70k positives to break the minimum threshold for an average of 14k/day. New positives have been decelerating, but not at a rate fast enough to average 14k/day or less unless something drastic changes. The second band represents an average of 14k-24k/day, most recent new positives have been in the 20-30k/day range, so I believe that is the most likely bucket, but there is always a chance that testing protocols could change. At home tests were just FDA approved and widespread testing could be rolled out. Also the definition of a "positive" could change, especially as more antibody studies are conducted, so I assigned a non-zero, decreasing probability to buckets 3-5.
Modeling looking at testing with growth of testing expected

Adjusting based on latest number of tests and yesterday’s new cases. I also think I might have been under-estimating the surge in testing (thanks @Anneinak). That being said, I think the recently-announced increases (enough to test 2% of Americans) won’t be in place by the time this question ends.

Again, I am assuming that the trend remains relatively linear and there are no significant changes in counting method, testing or changes to historical data. However, each bracket is quite narrow so the room for error is high, especially with many days before the cut off date. Additionally, at this stage I feel that efforts to curb the spread will be largely offset by the attempts to resume 'business as usual'.
I was exceptionally good in changing my selection last minute and got it wrong in the forecasts before. So, let's see if I can break the habit this time.

For the forecast ending April 12, GJO's high forecast was safely in the middle of a 100k-wide bin. For April 19, we sneaked into the "right" bin of 700-750k by a mere 800 cases; the total caseload that week was 749,200. For the April 26 forecast, we missed slightly, giving 900-950k a forecast likelihood of 65% but then seeing the final number as 959k.  Question: Do we as a group think too linearly in an exponential world, causing underestimates?

Assumptions:
-the growth rate will be a straight line, not an exponential curve
-# of tests will continue to increase . . .  to 2% of each state per month or higher
-% of newly tested who are positive will continue to decline both because of social distancing and people being tested to verify uninfected status to be able to return to work.
Based on current trends, approximately 30k are being added per day.
Factoring in a higher number of tests being performed in the next week compared with previously.

Model [1] that does the following: 1. Projects linearly based on declining growth slope since (what looks like) the peak on Fri, Apr 10th
2. Adjusts for day of week variation - there's clear day-of-week variation where counts on Sat/Sun/Mon/Tue are lower than expected if following a perfect linear slope, and counts on Wed/Thu/Fri are higher than expected. See graph on model spreadsheet.
3. Dials up the confidence by reducing standard deviation around the projected mean (projected count minus today's count, divided by 6) Forecast: 1,154,187 [1] https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ZN2wk0VBJpuMyQy0ZZqL-1qJw8m_biLuuz5yo9n9hTE/edit#gid=317806076

https://coronavirus.1point3acres.com/en/test
If you look at last 8 days there is a positive rate for tests of about 14% but overall is 17%. Supposedly tests will double in next week but so far a high of about 315,000 in a day. If they could keep up the 315,000 there would be added about 2,205,000 tests to the present total of 5,457,990. 14% of that is about 1,079,000. Dr Birx said test would double in next week but really? Going with the 315,000 a day mostly now because they have not even sustained that yet. The number of tests and daily percent makes a difference.
29.8k, 28.4k 7 day avgs.  Avg increase small despite increased testing. Won't sustain as pool of cases left to detect drops off. Above 1,150,000 plausible but not high chance.

Logarithmic regression in the day-over-day change in new cases suggests the rate slowing from 2.9% increase per day to 1.5% increase per day. That trend would suggest 1,099,787 cases by eod on 5/3 - really close to the line. Tilting my bet to the low end since there is some serial correlation to the residuals that is pointing downward Surge in testing capacity could render this approach invalid, but given both material and lab constraints, that could be difficult over such a short horizon. Will continue updating as new data comes in.
No sign that total cases are slowing down linearly, maybe this week will show more information
